intro: Lipotriche robinsonii, commonly known as the Robinson's lipotriche, is a rare flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton, and is characterized by its showy, five-petaled flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, wooded areas and has hairy, lance-shaped leaves. Its flowers are usually pink to purple in color and bloom during the summer months. Due to habitat loss, it is considered threatened and requires conservation efforts to ensure its survival.
